contextId.occurrenceNote: The second sentence means basically the same thing as the first and is added for clarification. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Then each man ... identified his ancestry. He had to name the clans and families descended from his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize that he obeyed Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: following the word of Yahweh, just as he was commanded to do

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: he was told to do by Yahweh's word, as Yahweh had commanded him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: to his work, to his special tasks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and may be combined to state that the offerings that someone gives belong to the priest to whom they have been given. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The offerings of every person will be for the priest; if anyone gives anything to the priest, it will belong to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize that he must obey the obligations of his vow. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: he must keep the obligations ... to keep the promise indicated by the law for the Nazirite

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases describe the same group of people two different ways. Alternate translation: "the leaders of Israel who are also the heads of their ancestors families" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the leaders of Israel ... the heads of their ancestor's families

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases describe the same location. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: from above the atonement lid ... from between the two cherubim

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasize the firstborn sons. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: each male child who opens the womb, the firstborn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here there are three parallel sentences that give the same information. It is repeated to emphasize that the people did to the Levites as Yahweh had commanded. Alternate translation: "Moses, Aaron, and the whole community of the people of Israel did with the Levites everything that Yahweh had commanded Moses concerning the Levites" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Moses, Aaron, and the whole community of the people of Israel ... The people of Israel did this with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize that they needed to obey the commands. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: follow all the regulations, and obey all the decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: "that stranger must keep it and do all that Yahweh has commanded concerning the Passover." The words "statute" and "rule" mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize that the stranger must obey all of the rules about the Passover. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: he must keep it according to the statute of the Passover and according to its rule

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases refer to the same group of people. Here the second phrase is used to describe the first phrase. Alternate translation: "the leaders, who are the heads of the clans of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the leaders, the heads of the clans of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize that God punished them immediately, even while they were eating the meat. Alternate translation: "While they were still eating the meat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: While the meat was still between their teeth, while they were chewing it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "against Moses" clarifies that he is the "servant" of whom Yahweh speaks. Alternate translation: "against my servant, Moses" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: against my servant, against Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: We will die here. We will all perish!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: "Every firstborn male" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Everything that opens the womb, all the firstborn

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phrases refer to the same thing. Together they emphasize that the covenant will endure forever. Alternate translation: "an agreement forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: an everlasting covenant of salt ... a binding covenant forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will remain unclean; his uncleanness will remain on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. They mean that it is time for Aaron to die and for his spirit to go to the place where his ancestors are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: must die and be gathered to his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the role of the leaders in digging the well. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the well that our leaders dug, the well the nobles of the people dug

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are two names that refer to the same city. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Heshbon ... city of Sihon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that destruction will begin at Heshbon. The fire refers to a destroying army. Alternate translation: "King Sihon led a strong army from the city of Heshbon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: A fire blazed from Heshbon, a flame from the city of Sihon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases refer to the same people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab ... people of Chemosh

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing, and emphasize how afraid Moab was. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab was very afraid of the people ... Moab was in terror of the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Balak has brought me from Aram ... the king of Moab from the eastern mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. They emphasize that Balak wants Balaam to curse the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: 'Come, curse Jacob for me,' ... 'Come, defy Israel.'

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Balaam viewed Israel from the top of a hill. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: from the top of the rocks I see him ... from the hills I look at him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize how important it was for Balak to pay attention. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Balak, and hear ... Listen to me, you son of Zippor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these questions mean the same thing and emphasize that God does what he says he will. These rhetorical questions can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: "He has never promised a thing without fulfilling what he promised. He has always done exactly what he said he would do." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Has he promised anything without doing it? Has he said he would do something without carrying it out?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Possible meanings are 1) God has given Israel only good things or 2) there is no sin in Israel that would cause him to judge them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: hardship in Jacob ... trouble in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean the same thing, that no curse that anyone puts on the nation of Israel will be effective. Here "Jacob" is a metonym that refers to Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: There is no sorcery that works against Jacob ... no fortune-telling harms Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. They emphasize the Israelite camp was beautiful to Balaam. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: How beautiful are your tents, Jacob, the place where you live, Israel!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meaning, emphasizing how much God will bless them compared to other nations. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Their king is to be higher ... their kingdom will be honored

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Balaam is having a vision of a future event. The word "him" refers to a future leader of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I see him, but he is not here now. I look at him, but he is not near

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the same thing as the first part of the sentence. Here "scepter" refers to a powerful king. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: a scepter will rise out of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean the same thing, and they are used together for emphasis. Alternate translation: "both he and the entire nation of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: both he and all the people of Israel with him, the whole community

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences have similar meanings and are combined to emphasize that he must fulfill his promises. Here "word" is a metonym that refers to what he said. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: he must not break his word. He must keep his promise to do everything that comes out of his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the vow that she has made ... that is, the rash talk of her lips." These two phrases refer to the same thing. The second phrase describes the vow that the woman made. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the vow that she has made ... the rash talk of her lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. This is a polite way to emphasize that it is time for Moses to die and for his spirit to go to the place where his ancestors are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: you will die and be gathered to your people
